channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Rash of Taliban Attacks Leaves 20 Afghan Police Officers Dead
item.description: In one assault, insurgents besieged a government headquarters in a district capital, and 40 officials were reported trapped in an underground bunker.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND

item.title: A Recovery That Needs a Recovery: United Nations Forecasts Persistently High Unemployment for the Young
item.description: The world economy is expected to continue to sputter in the near future, at a time when more young people are entering the job market than ever before.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: Unemployed citizens waiting in lines to register at the Employment Exchange Office in Allahabad, India, in March 2013. One million Indians are due to join the labor market every month for the next 15 years.

item.title: Tadeusz Rozewicz, Fierce Poetic Voice of Postwar Poland, Is Dead at 92
item.description: Mr. Rozewicz, whose youth was spent in war, survived to become one of Poland’s most distinguished literary voices.
item.dc:creator: By DOUGLAS MARTIN
item.media:description: Tadeusz Rozewicz, left, with his Polish literary colleague Czeslaw Milosz at the Frankfurt book fair in October 2000.

item.title: India Ink: Meet Modi’s Potential Foreign Policy Team
item.description: Here are some of the key players who have been named as possible members of the prime minister-elect’s foreign policy and security teams.
item.dc:creator: By JYOTI MALHOTRA

item.title: 2 Explosions Kill Scores at Central Nigeria Market
item.description: The blasts in the city of Jos detonated within minutes of each other, leaving at least 58 people dead, and the second explosion might have been timed to kill rescuers.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Nigerians waited on Tuesday for fires to subside after two deadly blasts ripped through a marketplace filled with afternoon shoppers in Jos.

item.title: World Briefing: Groups Pool Funds to Protect More of Amazon Rain Forest
item.description: An agreement between government and private partners will allow for an additional 34,000 square miles of Brazilian rain forest to be added to a conservation program.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES

item.title: Day 4: Life’s Celebrations
item.description: A day-by-day journey up Interstate 35 continues with a look at the personal milestones of a handful of people in and around Cotulla, Tex. — from birthdays to wedding vows to a blessing before heading to college.

item.title: China and Russia Reach 30-Year Gas Deal
item.description: Capping a decade-long negotiation, the two countries agreed on Wednesday to a deal, expected to be worth about $400 billion, that would send gas from Siberia by pipeline to China.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ
item.media:credit: Alexei Druzhinin/Presidential Press Service, via Associated Press
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and President Xi Jinping of China stood during the signing of a gas deal on Wednesday in Shanghai.

item.title: Egyptian Court Convicts Mubarak of Embezzlement
item.description: Former President Hosni Mubarak was sentenced to three years in prison on Wednesday after a court convicted him of diverting millions of dollars in public money for his personal use.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Former President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, who was convicted on Wednesday of conspiring to embezzle more than $17 million.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Under Pressure, ‘Naked Official’ Chooses Early Retirement
item.description: The details of Fang Xuan’s forced retirement offer a glimpse into how China is dealing with its longstanding problem of “naked officials” — those who have packed off their family and, often, ill-gotten wealth abroad.
item.category: Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (Communist Party of China)
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: A Military Brat on Okinawa
item.description: Growing up, I didn’t appreciate the cost of America’s occupation. Now I do.
item.dc:creator: By SARAH BIRD

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Turkey’s Dickensian Disaster
item.description: The prime minister would rather slap protesters than take responsibility for a tragedy.
item.dc:creator: By MUSTAFA AKYOL

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Go Beyond Diplomacy on Syria
item.description: The United States needs to provide covert assistance to moderate Syrian opposition groups.
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN STEVENSON

item.title: Thai Military Tries to Break Political Deadlock as Foes Meet
item.description: The meeting organized by the military a day after imposing martial law was the first time that all sides in Thailand’s current political impasse sat down together.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: Investors Await Cues on Modi’s Economic Policy
item.description: Foreign and domestic investors are keenly awaiting the appointment of the finance minister and the announcement of the new government’s first budget, while keeping tabs on speculation about a possible change in leadership at the central bank.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Arun Jaitley, a senior leader of the Bharatiya Janata Party, arriving at the Parliament house in New Delhi on Tuesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: A Life Collecting Chinese Landscapes
item.description: Lois Conner has devoted three decades to making landscapes of China layered with detail and history.
item.category: The New York Times Lens Blog
item.dc:creator: By RENA SILVERMAN
item.media:description: Hall of Peaceful Seas (Haiyantang). Yuanming Yuan. 2000.

item.title: Pakistani Military Says It Killed 32 Militants in Raids
item.description: At least 32 people suspected of being militants were killed Wednesday in what the Pakistani military said were terrorist hide-outs across the North Waziristan tribal region.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Chinese Company Puts Death Toll in Vietnam Riots at 4
item.description: The China Metallurgical Group has announced that four Chinese workers were killed in rioting at a steel mill being built in central Vietnam, a toll from the anti-Chinese unrest last week that would double the overall count previously given by Chinese government officials.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese workers who were injured by Vietnamese protesters last week recovering at Ha Tinh General Hospital.

item.title: Offering Brighter Outlook, Japan’s Central Bank Holds on Stimulus
item.description: The governor of the Bank of Japan reiterated his optimism that the country is on course to meet the bank’s 2 percent inflation target.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Volunteers Spend 105 Days in Capsule in Dry Run for Space
item.description: The researchers raised plants and ate bugs to study how to survive in a space station or lunar base for extended periods.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: The Lede: Young Iranians Arrested for Being Too ‘Happy in Tehran’
item.description: The teenagers were forced to repent on state television Tuesday after proclaiming themselves to be “Happy in Tehran” in a music video that they posted on YouTube.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: An image of the "Happy in Tehran" dancers posted on Instagram.

item.title: House Measure to Change Voice of America’s Mission Is Drawing Intense Debate
item.description: Supporters of the bill see a countering of Russian disinformation, while detractors see an American propaganda tool.
item.dc:creator: By RON NIXON
item.media:description: Representative Ed Royce calls the legislation essential.

item.title: Memo Approving Targeted Killing of U.S. Citizen to Be Released
item.description: The Obama administration said it would release much of a memo that concluded it was lawful to kill Anwar al-Awlaki, an American who was killed by a drone strike in Yemen in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By ASHLEY PARKER

item.title: British Officials Welcome Cleric’s Conviction, but Some Britons Are Wary
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron and his home secretary praised the terrorism conviction in New York of Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, but some Muslims in London expressed concern.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Iraq: Attacks Kill 13, Including Off-Duty Soldiers
item.description: A police official said the deadliest attack took place at night, when gunmen ambushed a minibus carrying off-duty soldiers near the town of Suleiman Beg.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
